Message.Title: DIPSHIDIOT'S DIARY
Message.Msg: Thu Oct 18, 2012 at 06:00 PM PDT The Chronicles of Mitt: Oct 18, 2012 by Hunter pen on paper: 'Dear diary' Hello, human diary. It is I again, Mitt Romney, your better. I am very angry with my advisers today, Mr. Diary. Turning on the television today, I have heard nothing but my staff, surrogates, and assorted other hangers-on discussing my opinions on various issues. Ed G. apparently told the press I did not support a certain bill regarding wages for females. He then stated I did support it. Then another staff member said I mostly did, but partly did not. Then someone else said I did not, but that I supported the principle of it, or at least the part of the principle that I did support but not the part that I did not support. This is why I do not watch the television very often. I finally could take no more of it, and summoned my staff and advisers for an urgent conference call, which I used to angrily demand members of my campaign stop claiming to the press that I had opinions on various important issues facing the nation. I do not have opinions on various important issues facing the nation, I am running for office for Pete's sake. I do not remember ever expressing an opinion on any issue, I reminded them, other than wealthy Americans like myself deserve a large tax cut. And by tax cut, I currently mean that it would not be a tax cut, but merely an adjustment of the rates of various taxes in such a way as to achieve no actual tax cut, unless by coincidence a wealthy American happened to have most of their income invested in the various places that I intend to cut taxes. So it is not even accurate to say that I support lowering taxes, because I do not, I merely favor a multivectored tax adjustment that will accomplish nothing in particular. I then sent my staff out with the instruction that my opinion on very large tax cuts that will not cut taxes is the only issue that they may state I have an opinion on. I am beginning to fear all of these people are as dull as the commoners are. It is true that none of them are as wealthy as I am, but stillâ€”many of them are at least slightly wealthy. One would think they would be able to keep track of these things.

Message.Title: A Little Knowledge Is Dangerous
Message.Msg: In May 2009, my son was in a horrific accident, 3 months in intensive care, and I made some investments for him, forseeing a long recovery. Etrade was one of them, it was $1.50#$%$ the time, , and although I knew about the mortgage end of the business, i figured they'd work it off over time (18 months I thought). Also, given that Citadel had come to their rescue, I figured they had the backing of a pretty smart hedge fund. Well............I was wrong on all points. The bad bank side was far worse than I thought, we are now down to 90 cents/sh (pre-reverse split), and Citadel really hasn't done much for shareholders except for themselves as they probably short the stock. Today's $50 million debacle was a shocker, and eye opener for me. And, to make it worse, a failed CEO walks away with a $13 million severance package. That's the worst stick in the eye. I simply didn't understand the complexities or severity of these bank bad lending issues, a little knowledge is dangerous. Thankfully,.I made some good investments too for my son, and it looks like Etrade is going to be nothing more than a tax loss writeoff against those profits. Lessons learned.

Message.Title: long term buy
Message.Msg: based on the trends in the write downs and the size of their mortgage portfolio I figure Etrade needs to set aside another billion dollars for bad mortgages in the next 5 years. They are going to on average set aside 70 million a quarter for the next few quarters and at the end of 5 years I figure they'll be down to 20 to 30 million. It's a long slog but at the end of 5 years thy'll be making at least $1 a share.

Message.Title: President Romney is beating Obama.in all polls
Salt Lake Tribune endorses BO
Message.Msg: Too many Mitts Obama has earned another term First Published 56 minutes ago â€¢ Updated 28 minutes ago Nowhere has Mitt Romneyâ€™s pursuit of the presidency been more warmly welcomed or closely followed than here in Utah. The Republican nomineeâ€™s political and religious pedigrees, his adeptly bipartisan governorship of a Democratic state, and his head for business and the bottom line all inspire admiration and hope in our largely Mormon, Republican, business-friendly state. But it was Romneyâ€™s singular role in rescuing Utahâ€™s organization of the 2002 Olympics from a cesspool of scandal, and his oversight of the most successful Winter Games on record, that make him the Beehive Stateâ€™s favorite adopted son. After all, Romney managed to save the state from ignominy, turning the extravaganza into a showcase for the matchless landscapes, volunteerism and efficiency that told the world what is best and most beautiful about Utah and its people. Photos In short, this is the Mitt Romney we knew, or thought we knew, as one of us. Sadly, it is not the only Romney, as his campaign for the White House has made abundantly clear, first in his servile courtship of the tea party in order to win the nomination, and now as the partyâ€™s shape-shifting nominee. From his embrace of the partyâ€™s radical right wing, to subsequent portrayals of himself as a moderate champion of the middle class, Romney has raised the most frequently asked question of the campaign: "Who is this guy, really, and what in the world does he truly believe?" The evidence suggests no clear answer, or at least one that would survive Romneyâ€™s next speech or sound bite. Politicians routinely tailor their words to suit an audience. Romney, though, is shameless, lavishing vastly diverse audiences with words, any words, they would trade their votes to hear. More troubling, Romney has repeatedly refused to share specifics of his radical plan to simultaneously reduce the debt, get rid of Obamacare (or, as he now says, only part of it), make a voucher program of Medicare, slash taxes and spending, and thereby create millions of new jobs. To claim, as Romney does, that he would offset his tax and spending cuts (except for billions more for the military) by doing away with tax deductions and exemptions, is utterly meaningless without identifying which and how many would get the ax. Absent those specifics, his promise of a balanced budget simply does not pencil out. If this portrait of a Romney willing to say anything to get elected seems harsh, we need only revisit his branding of 47 percent of Americans as freeloaders who pay no taxes, yet feel victimized and entitled to government assistance. His job, he told a group of wealthy donors, "is not to worry about those people. Iâ€™ll never convince them they should take personal responsibility and care for their lives." Where, we ask, is the pragmatic, inclusive Romney, the Massachusetts governor who left the state with a model health care plan in place, the Romney who led Utah to Olympic glory? That Romney skedaddled and is nowhere to be found. And what of the president Romney would replace? For four years, President Barack Obama has attempted, with varying degrees of success, to pull the nation out of its worst financial meltdown since the Great Depression, a deepening crisis he inherited the day he took office. In the first months of his presidency, Obama acted decisively to stimulate the economy. His leadership was essential to passage of the badly needed American Recovery and Reinvestment Act. Though Republicans criticize the stimulus for failing to create jobs, it clearly helped stop the hemorrhaging of public sector jobs. The Utah Legislature used hundreds of millions in stimulus funds to plug holes in the stateâ€™s budget. The president also acted wisely to bail out the auto industry, which has since come roaring back. Romney, in so many words, said the carmakers should sink if they canâ€™t swim. Obamaâ€™s most noteworthy achievement, passage of his signature Affordable Care Act, also proved, in its timing, his greatest blunder. The set of comprehensive health insurance reforms aimed at extending health care coverage to all Americans was signed 14 months into his term after a ferocious fight in Congress that sapped the new presidentâ€™s political capital and destroyed any chance for bipartisan cooperation on the shredded economy. Obamaâ€™s foreign policy record is perhaps his strongest suit, especially compared to Romneyâ€™s bellicose posture toward Russia and China and his inflammatory rhetoric regarding Iranâ€™s nuclear weapons program. Obamaâ€™s measured reliance on tough economic embargoes to bring Iran to heel, and his equally measured disengagement from the war in Afghanistan, are examples of a nuanced approach to international affairs. The glaring exception, still unfolding, was the administrationâ€™s failure to protect the lives of the U.S. ambassador to Libya and three other Americans, and to quickly come clean about it. In considering which candidate to endorse, The Salt Lake Tribune editorial board had hoped that Romney would exhibit the same talents for organization, pragmatic problem-solving and inspired leadership that he displayed here more than a decade ago. Instead, we have watched him morph into a friend of the far right, then tack toward the center with breathtaking aplomb. Through a pair of presidential debates, Romneyâ€™s domestic agenda remains bereft of detail and worthy of mistrust. Therefore, our endorsement must go to the incumbent, a competent leader who, against tough odds, has guided the country through catastrophe and set a course that, while rocky, is pointing toward a brighter day. The president has earned a second term. Romney, in whatever guise, does not deserve a first.

Topic.Title: long term buy

Message.Msg: There is no way ETFC deserves a similar multiple as AMTD first of all. One has a real management that understands its core business the other one is vehicle of wealth redistribution from the shareholders to the constantly rotating management team (nice revlving door as we call it). Second of all, the core brokerage business is in a really bad spot here. there is a severe oversaturation in the industry (there is going to be less demand for brokers as the population continues to get poorer). Therefore there has to be strong consolidation in the industry. It will first start with a wave of bankruptices of smaller brokers around the US (that wave has already started), followed by powerful multiple contraction as growth opportunities diminish, and lastly, end with a wave of large M&A transactions as the stronger players scoop up the weaker ones at very low valuations. I argue this will unfold within the next 3-5 years. At that point I expect for the stronger players to trade at 10x-12x and weaker players have no earnings and be sold at 0.2x-0.3x book multiples. That is the likely scenario for this dog, to be acquired at 0.3x BV at $5-$6 per share. i've seen this and analyzed this before during the many years I've been an analyst. Nothing different here.
